title-group.article-title: Endovascular Treatment of an Iatrogenic Large Vessel Arteriovenous Fistula Presenting as High Output Heart Failure
title-group.subtitle: A Case Report

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Surgery, University of Ulsan College of Medicine and Gangneung Asan Hospital, Gangneung, Korea
2Department of Radiology, University of Ulsan College of Medicine and Asan Medical Center, Seoul, Korea
3Division of Vascular Surgery, Department of Surgery, University of Ulsan College of Medicine and Asan Medical Center, Seoul, Korea

author-notes.corresp: Yong-Pil Cho, Division of Vascular Surgery, Department of Surgery, University of Ulsan College of Medicine and Asan Medical Center, Asanbyeongwon-gil 86, Songpa-gu, Seoul 138-736, Korea Email: ypcho@amc.seoul.kr

abstract.p: Formation of an iatrogenic chronic large vessel arteriovenous (AV) fistula is an uncommon, early or late complication of spine surgery and associated with serious consequences. Its diagnosis is often delayed for months or years after the occurrence and rarely only after the patient develops heart failure secondary to a mature AV fistula. We present the case of a 43-year-old man with high-output heart failure due to an iatrogenic large vessel AV fistula after lumbar disc surgery successfully treated with the endovascular technique.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Because of the anatomical relation between the lumbar vertebrae and the anterior abdominal vasculature, vascular injuries may occur during an operation for herniated lumbar disc. 1
–5 Although large vessel injuries that complicate spine surgery are rare, diagnosis is often delayed for months or years after the occurrence and it may be potentially fatal. 1
–5 Therefore, early diagnosis and treatment of vascular complications associated with spine surgery can prevent a serious clinical outcome.

High-output heart failure can occur as a result of systemic illnesses or of arteriovenous (AV) fistulae either congenital or iatrogenic, as well as blunting or penetrating trauma. 3 Herein, we report a rare case with high-output heart failure due to an iatrogenic AV fistula between the right common iliac artery and the right internal iliac vein after lumbar disc surgery that was successfully treated with the endovascular technique.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: A 43-year-old man was admitted to cardiovascular unit with a 3-week history of palpitation and dyspnea on exertion. The past clinical history was completely unremarkable except for 2 operations for L3-L4 herniated disc at an outside facility, 12 years and 2 years before, respectively.

On admission, the clinical examination demonstrated bilateral basal rales and an abdominal bruit in the right lower abdominal area. His initial blood chemistry values were within normal limits. The chest x-ray showed dilated cardiac contour, suggesting cardiac congestion (Figure 1). On the basis of the patient’s symptoms and physical findings, a fistula with congestive heart failure was suspected. A transthoracic echocardiogram showed enlarged right ventricle (45 mm on diastole), mild-to-moderate tricuspid and mitral valve regurgitation, and inferior vena cava plethora with dilation (33 mm). A multi-detector computed tomographic (CT) scan revealed a 20-mm sized saccular aneurysm of the right common iliac artery, abnormally connected with the right iliac vein and early venous return to the inferior vena cava and bilateral iliac veins, suggested the diagnosis of an AV fistula between the right common iliac artery and the right iliac vein (Figure 2). However, the exact point of the fistula could not be identified because of simultaneous opacification of the inferior vena cava, bilateral iliac veins, and the right common iliac artery with massively dilated vena cava and iliac veins. Digital subtraction angiogram confirmed a fistulous connection between the right common iliac artery and the right internal iliac vein. Following embolization of the right internal iliac artery using the Amplatzer vascular plug (AGA Medical, Golden Valley, Minnesota; arrow) and N-butyl-2-cyanoacrylate (histoacryl; Braun, Germany) to prevent type II endoleak, a 22/12 × 70 mm Seal Thoracic Stent-Graft (S & G Biotech Inc, Gyeonggi-do, Korea) was placed from the aortic bifurcation to the right external iliac artery in correspondence of the fistula. Final angiogram demonstrated completely occluded AV fistula with patent arterial flow on both low extremities (Figure 3).

caption.p: Initial chest x-ray showed dilated cardiac contour, suggesting cardiac congestion.
A coronal reconstructed maximum intensity processing computed tomographic image showed distended the vena cava and bilateral iliac veins due to early venous return via an arteriovenous fistula.

A, Aortogram demonstrated early opacification of the dilated bilateral iliac veins and the vena cava through a large arteriovenous fistula tract (arrow) at the right common iliac artery. Curved arrow indicated the right internal iliac artery. B, After embolization of the right internal iliac artery (arrow), a stent-graft (curved arrows) was placed from the aortic bifurcation to the right external iliac artery. C, Final aortogram demonstrated completely occluded the arteriovenous fistula.

sec.p: Two weeks later, the patient was completely asymptomatic. Follow-up multi-detector CT scan and chest x-ray revealed complete repair of an AV fistula and dramatic resolution of dilated cardiac contour (Figure 4). Eighteen months follow-up is completed without any other complication.

caption.p: A, Two weeks follow-up coronal reconstructed maximum intensity processing computed tomographic image showed patent arterial flow on both low extremities with disappeared arteriovenous fistula. B, Chest x-ray obtained 2 weeks after stent-graft placement showed normalized cardiac contour.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Reported iatrogenic causes of abdominal vascular injury are invasive diagnostic procedures, abdominal operations, spine operations, and adjuncts to cardiac surgery (cardiopulmonary bypass, intra-aortic balloon assist, etc). 1 Even more rare, abdominal vascular injury during an operation for a herniated lumbar disc as a major complication can be seen because of the intimate anatomical relation between the lumbar vertebrae and major vessels. 1,4 Although the incidence of vascular injuries following spine surgery is reported to be 1 to 5 per 10 000, iatrogenic vascular injuries might be underestimated because clinical manifestations may be extremely variable depending on the type of trauma. 1 –3,6 A literature review by Papadoulas et al identified 98 patients with vascular injuries following spine surgery: laceration (30%), AV fistula with or without pseudoaneurysm (67%), and pseudoaneurysm alone (3%). 2

The mechanism of AV fistula formation following spine surgery is penetration of the anterior longitudinal ligament with surgical instruments, injuring the aorta, vena cava, or iliac vessels. 7 The formation of an AV fistula is a late complication of vascular injury during spine surgery although it may sometimes be of acute onset. 2 Chronic AV fistulae mimic congestive heart failure accompanied by an abdominal bruit and leg edema. The clinical features are important for the diagnosis of AV fistulae, but classic features of this condition may be absent in approximately on half of the patients. 1 Absence of classic features, together with the rarity of such lesions and resultant lack of awareness, may lead to delay in diagnosis for months or years. Consequently, about 25% of AV fistulae remain unrecognized even after 1 year has lapsed. 1,2 In our patient, there were no clinical signs of vascular injury during and early after the lumbar disc surgery, and the AV fistula was diagnosed approximately 2 years following the surgery. Noninvasive diagnostic imaging studies, including color Doppler ultrasound, dynamic CT scan, or magnetic resonance imaging, can confirm the diagnosis. Angiography, the “gold standard” for diagnosing vascular complications after spine surgery, is indicated when the clinical findings are unclear or endovascular stent-graft placement is considered as an alternative to a surgical procedure. 1
–5

The AV fistulae following spine surgery can be treated with surgical exploration or endovascular techniques. 1 Since Cooley reported the first successful repair of a large vessel AV fistula in 1955, open repair has been considered as the treatment of choice for large vessel AV fistulae. 8 However, it may be difficult to access the injury because of enlargement of upstream arteries and numerous engorged retroperitoneal veins, which may be complicated with extensive blood loss if inadvertently incised. Difficult dissection also increases the risk of nerve and other organ injuries. In addition, patients with high-output heart failure may not tolerate general anesthesia and major operation. 5 Although some series have reported operative mortality rates as low as 6%, with the majority of deaths occurring in patients not correctly diagnosed with large vessel AV fistulae preoperatively, open repair still has substantial mortality and significant morbidity rates. 9 –11 Currently, successful endovascular treatment of aortocaval fistulae associated with abdominal aortic aneurysms and aortic anastomotic pseudoaneurysms using stent-grafts has been reported, and some authors have recommended less invasive endovascular techniques for the treatment of large vessel AV fistulae following spine surgery rather than surgical approaches. 1
–5,7,12 Endovascular repair is simpler, quicker, and cosmetically more acceptable than surgical repair. 13 Furthermore, in cases with hemodynamically unstable vital signs or other comorbidities, endovascular techniques can be used to reduce the perioperative mortality and morbidity rates. 1

It is well known that the development of high-output heart failure in a young patient, who has recently undergone lumbar disc surgery is almost diagnostic of iatrogenic AV fistula. 2,14,15 In our patient, his initial clinical presentation was palpitation and dyspnea on exertion, suggestive of high-output heart failure, and he also had a previous medical history of 2 operations for herniated lumbar disc. His diagnosis of an iatrogenic chronic AV fistula after lumbar disc surgery was made by noninvasive and invasive diagnostic imaging studies. Although noninvasive diagnostic imaging study, a multi-detector CT scan, could not identify the exact point of the fistula, invasive study, digital subtraction angiogram, confirmed a fistulous connection between the right common iliac artery and the right internal iliac vein. Considering that the perioperative mortality and morbidity may be substantially high in this case because of massively dilated inferior vena cava and both iliac veins with numerous collateral vessels and expected severe fibrosis of the operative field following 2 previous operations, the patient underwent an endovascular stent-graft placement as the first-line treatment. We used an endoprosthesis, designed for the thoracic aorta, which was long enough to cover the fistula with a large diameter and provide for adequate proximal and distal seal zones utilizing a single piece. 11 The endovascular procedure was performed successfully in our patient without any complications. Immediately after the procedure, his clinical symptoms resolved completely, and chest x-ray obtained 2 weeks after stent-graft placement showed normalized cardiac contour.

We add to the literature an additional case of successful endovascular repair of an iliac artery-to-iliac vein fistula, discovered 2 years after operations for herniated lumbar disc, in a young patient presenting with high-output heart failure. Endovascular repair of an iatrogenic large vessel AV fistula has many potential advantages over open repair, including lower mortality and morbidity, particularly in patients with a hostile abdomen, rapid recovery, and shorter hospital stays. Therefore, endovascular techniques should be considered the first-line therapy for any such iatrogenic injuries when the clinical presentation permits preprocedural evaluation with imaging and planning of appropriate repair.
